channel.title: Rob Wiederstein -- a blog about data
channel.description: Recent content on Rob Wiederstein -- a blog about data

item.title: HUGO Variables
item.description: hugo has three kinds of variables: (1) resident or “built-in” global variables, (2) defined global variables in the config file and (3) page variables. Site Variables List To see the configuration settings for hugo run: hugo config .Site.Params Variable A bunch of code here {{ $_hugo_config := { "version": 1 } }} hugo-variables If you've ever wondered exactly how Shiny's reactive graph works, I have new "Mastering Shiny" book chapter up: https://t.

item.title: Ten Tips to Working with Go Templates
item.description: Introduction hugo templates are based on the go language, but are derived from the go template library. It is simple and relies on only basic logic. go templates are html documents whose variables and functions are accessible via {{-}}. Variable # predefined variable {{ .Title }} # custom variable {{ $address }} Function # general syntax # {{ FUNCTION ARG1 ARG2 .. }} {{ add 1 2 }} Dot Notation # Access Page Parameter "bar"" defined in page front matter.

item.title: CV
item.description: Presentations: Recollections from 18 Years of Judging (Henderson Rotary Club, Early Learning Ctr., Sept. 29, 2016). The Role of the Constitution, Campaign Finance, and the Presidential Race of 2016 (Henderson Community College, Henderson, Ky., Sept. 21, 2016). Center for Youth Justice and Services: Making Our Community Safer One Kid at a Time (Co-presenter, Alternatives to Detention Conference, Embassy Suites, Louisville, Ky., Aug. 26, 2016).

item.title: Insert HTML Widgets in Blogdown
item.description: Load Libraries Insert Data Tables or DT Widget Insert Leaflet Widget Insert Sigma JS Insert Plotly Widget There were two main reasons for moving to blogdown. First, I needed a blogging platform that moved seemlessly between R code and its output. It had to be easy to show the connection between the code that was used and its effect on the data.

item.title: Code Highlighting in Rmarkdown
item.description: Example 1 Example 2 Example 1 # Dr Seuss a <- 1:2 fish.number <- paste(a, "fish", sep ="_") b <- c("red", "blue") fish.color <- paste(b, "fish", sep = "_") print(c(fish.number, fish.color)) ## [1] "1_fish" "2_fish" "red_fish" "blue_fish" Example 2 data(mtcars) p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(hp,mpg, group = factor(cyl), color = factor(cyl))) p <- p + geom_point() p <- p + ggtitle("Mtcars") p Figure 1: A plot constructed with ggplot2.

item.title: Datasets
item.description: Airlines & Airports Bureau of Transportation & Statistics. Cruise Ships Sample Cruise Ship Data. Economics Bureau of Economic Analysis. Federal Reserve Economic Data. Aswath Damodaran’s Data Sets. Organization of Economic Cooperation & Development. Education National Center for Education Statistics. Kentucky Department of Education. Kentucky Graduation Project Data. Energy Kentucky Coal Facts. US Energy Information Administration. Global Powerplant Database. General Socrata Open Data Resources.

item.title: Ten Tips to Working with Blogdown
item.description: Introduction Ten Tips Best Resources Introduction Transitioning to hugo is difficult. Blogdown offers the promise of an easy and quick workflow for blogging, however, that is not the case. If you’re not ready for some hard work, then you should probably stay with Wordpress or Squarespace. On the otherhand, if you want to understand the principles that underly much of webpage creation, then stick with blogdown and hugo.

item.title: Hello R Markdown
item.description: R Markdown Including Plots R Markdown This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com. You can place an R code chunk like this: summary(cars) ## speed dist ## Min. : 4.0 Min. : 2.00 ## 1st Qu.:12.0 1st Qu.: 26.00 ## Median :15.0 Median : 36.

item.title: A Plain Markdown Post
item.description: This is a post written in plain Markdown (*.md) instead of R Markdown (*.Rmd). The major differences are: You cannot run any R code in a plain Markdown document, whereas in an R Markdown document, you can embed R code chunks (```{r}); A plain Markdown post is rendered through Blackfriday, and an R Markdown document is compiled by rmarkdown and Pandoc. There are many differences in syntax between Blackfriday’s Markdown and Pandoc’s Markdown.

item.title: About
item.description: I’m a dad, a retired judge, a guitar player, a former state representative, an amateur programmer and statistician. Out of fear that some may take my posts too seriously, I describe myself as someone who does mostly exploratory analysis and visualization–although I have ventured into predictive analytics and modeling from time to time. The death of analytical/investigative reporting at the regional and local level often leads me into controversial areas like public policy.
